<td style={{ paddingLeft: '12px'}}>

Since the first version of React that I worked with (`0.2.3`), the platform, the tooling, licensing and a community has come a long way. But what is consistent since the very first version and the best feature of React is the approach it teaches you to build robust and scalable applications known as *component driven development*. Separating applications into dedicated, lean and pure components / functions, provides multitude of benefits, best described on [HiChroma blog](https://blog.hichroma.com/component-driven-development-ce1109d56c8e). 

There are several existing tools that help you develop, test and maintain component in isolation. Among the most popular are [Storybook](https://storybook.js.org) and [Cosmos](https://github.com/react-cosmos/react-cosmos). The paid [HiChroma](https://hichroma.com) platform built upon Storybook a platform for visual detection of regressions.
</td>
</tr>
</table>

While all the previously mentioned platforms are rather passive (they do not enter into active web development and rather serve the purpose of catalogues), there are more active visual tools that allow us to use React components in live development, for example [Framer](https://framer.com).

**Tory.js** stands in the middle of this landscape and aims to serve several purposes. While you can use it passively as a component catalogue, you can also use as a visual application and form designer similar to Framer X, working with live or fake data point. **It runs natively in the browser** and as a result you can embed the editor directly it in your application. Behold the editor in action.

<img src={tory} />

## The Philosophy

The *component-driven development* facilitates the application development and maintenance. The main problem of this approach is the estimation of granularity of your component stack, meaning: "Is a current functionality worth separating into a component?". If the breakdown is not done properly, we can either end up with few, very complex, fragile and hard to maintain components, or we end up with many small components, intertwined into fragile, complex structures.

<img src={lego} />


## Server + Express API

## The Technology Stack

Tory.js is primarily aimed at React users, yet the technology selected is framework agnostic. 

### Back End

<img width="300" src="https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*0HP2je9Tcm-64J4S-lQSgA.png" />

It connects to various back-ends. Currently we support native `fetch` operation to query `json` APIs as well as [GraphQL](https://www.apollographql.com) end points using [Apollo queries and mutations](components/apollo).

### Application State
 
<table>
  <tr>
    <td><a href="https://json-schema.org">
      <img src="https://json-schema.org/assets/logo.svg" height="100" /><br />
      Json Schema
      </a></td>
      <td> + </td>
      <td><a href="https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx-state-tree"><img src="https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx-state-tree/raw/master/docs/mobx-state-tree-logo-gradient.png" /><br />
      Mobx State Tree</a>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>

In Tory.js we relate to the application  form state as to **dataset**. The dataset is modeled and stored using the latest [JSON Schema, draft-07](https://json-schema.org) standard. It defines robust validations for all javascript types, including conditional validations. We use [ajv](https://github.com/epoberezkin/ajv), the fastest and most robust schema validator to bring you the best experience.

Using @toryjs/form package, we transform the json schema to a mobx-state-tree to provide reactive updates and the two-way data binding with your form components. Currently we support a bigger part of the draft-07 standard.
